canonical_explanation.text: Geometrical shapes are figures formed by points, lines, and curves. We study open and closed curves, polygons with straight sides, rectangles and squares with special properties, perpendicular and parallel lines, circles with centre and radius, symmetry in shapes, and how shapes fit together in patterns.
rules: A closed curve has no endpoints and encloses a region
A polygon is a simple closed curve made of line segments
A rectangle has 4 right angles and opposite sides equal
A square has 4 right angles and all 4 sides equal
Perpendicular lines meet at right angles
Parallel lines never meet and remain the same distance apart
The diameter of a circle is twice the radius: diameter = 2 × radius
A line of symmetry divides a shape into two identical halves

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a closed curve?

options.text: A curved line with two endpoints

questions.explanation_correct: A circle is a closed curve because it has no endpoints and the line goes all the way around to meet itself, forming a complete shape.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The letter C is an open curve because it has two endpoints and does not go all the way around to meet itself. A curved line with two endpoints and a wavy line are also open curves, which means they do not form a complete shape.

questions.question_text: A simple closed curve made of straight line segments is called a:
questions.explanation_correct: A polygon is a simple closed curve made of straight line segments. This is the correct answer because a polygon has straight sides, unlike a circle which is curved, or an open curve which is not closed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not correct. A circle is a curved shape, not made of straight line segments. An open curve is not closed, and an arc is just a part of a circle. Only a polygon, which is a closed shape made of straight lines, is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: How many right angles does a rectangle have?
questions.explanation_correct: A rectangle has 4 right angles. This means that all 4 corners of a rectangle form perfect 90-degree angles, or right angles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A rectangle does not have 2, 3, or 5 right angles. Each of the 4 corners of a rectangle forms a right angle, which is 90 degrees. So the correct answer is that a rectangle has 4 right angles.

questions.question_text: Which statement is true about a square?

options.text: It has 4 right angles but unequal sides
It has 4 equal sides and 4 right angles
It has 4 equal sides but no right angles
It has only opposite sides equal

questions.explanation_correct: A square has 4 equal sides and 4 right angles. This means all the angles are 90 degrees, making it a perfect rectangular shape.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is correct because a square has 4 equal sides and 4 right angles. This makes it a special type of rectangle. Options A and D are incorrect because a square must have all sides equal in length. Option C is incorrect because a square does have 4 right angles.

questions.question_text: Two lines that meet at a right angle are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Two lines that meet at a right angle (90 degrees) are called perpendicular lines. They form a perfect 'L' shape and are used to make shapes like squares and rectangles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Parallel lines are lines that never meet, even if you extend them very far. Diagonal lines are lines that connect two corners of a shape, like a square. Curved lines are lines that are not straight, like the shape of a circle. So the correct answer is that two lines meeting at a right angle are called perpendicular lines.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is true about parallel lines?

options.text: They never meet and remain the same distance apart

questions.explanation_correct: Parallel lines never meet and remain the same distance apart. They do not cross or intersect each other, and they are always the same distance from each other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Parallel lines do not meet at one point or cross each other. They also do not meet at right angles. Parallel lines are straight lines that are always the same distance apart and never intersect or touch each other.

questions.question_text: The point at the exact middle of a circle is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The point at the exact middle of a circle is called the centre. This is the fixed point from which all the points on the circle are an equal distance away.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The centre is the fixed point in the middle of the circle. It is not the radius, which is the line from the centre to the edge of the circle. It is also not the diameter, which is the line that goes through the centre and connects two points on the edge of the circle. And it is not the circumference, which is the distance all the way around the circle.

questions.question_text: If the radius of a circle is 5 cm, what is its diameter?
questions.explanation_correct: The diameter of a circle is twice the length of the radius. Since the radius of the circle is 5 cm, the diameter must be 10 cm (2 x 5 cm).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The diameter of a circle is the distance across the circle, from one side to the other. It is not the same as the radius, which is the distance from the center to the edge. To find the diameter, you need to double the radius, which is 5 cm. So the correct answer is 10 cm.

questions.question_text: A line that divides a shape into two identical halves is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A line of symmetry divides a shape into two identical halves. This means that if you fold the shape along this line, the two halves will match up perfectly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The line of symmetry is the correct answer because it is the line that divides a shape into two identical halves. A diagonal is a line that connects two corners of a shape, a perpendicular line is a line that forms a 90-degree angle with another line, and a parallel line is a line that is always the same distance from another line. None of these options divide the shape into two identical halves.

questions.question_text: How many pieces are there in a traditional tangram puzzle?
questions.explanation_correct: The traditional tangram puzzle has 7 pieces. This is the correct answer because a tangram is a Chinese puzzle made up of 7 flat geometric shapes - 5 triangles, 1 square, and 1 parallelogram.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The traditional tangram puzzle does not have 5, 6, or 8 pieces. It has 7 pieces - 5 triangles, 1 square, and 1 parallelogram. The 7 pieces fit together to form different shapes and patterns.

questions.question_text: A curve that starts and ends at the same point without crossing itself is called a ___ curve.
questions.explanation_correct: A closed curve is a curve that starts and ends at the same point without crossing itself. This means the shape is complete and forms a continuous loop.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The missing word is 'closed'. A closed curve is a curve that starts and ends at the same point without crossing itself. This means the shape is complete and forms a continuous loop. An open curve, on the other hand, has two separate endpoints and does not loop back on itself.

questions.question_text: A triangle is an example of a ___ because it is a simple closed curve made of straight line segments.
questions.explanation_correct: A triangle is an example of a polygon because it is a simple closed curve made of three straight line segments. Polygons are closed shapes with straight sides, and a triangle is the simplest polygon with three sides.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'polygon'. A triangle is a polygon because it is a closed shape made of straight line segments. The question asks for the type of shape a triangle is, and the answer 'polygon' is the correct one because a triangle has three straight sides that form a closed shape.

questions.question_text: In a rectangle, the opposite sides are always ___.
questions.explanation_correct: In a rectangle, the opposite sides are always equal because rectangles have four right angles and four sides that are parallel to each other. This means the opposite sides have the same length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The opposite sides of a rectangle are not always unequal. The correct answer is that the opposite sides are equal. Rectangles have four sides, and the two pairs of opposite sides are the same length. This is because rectangles have special properties, like parallel sides and right angles, that make the opposite sides equal.

questions.question_text: A square is a special type of rectangle where all ___ sides are equal in length.
questions.explanation_correct: A square is a type of rectangle where all four sides are equal in length. This is what makes a square a special kind of rectangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'four'. A square is a special type of rectangle where all the sides are equal in length. So, a square has four equal sides. The question is asking for the number of sides that are equal in a square, which is four.

questions.question_text: A ___ is a location in space that has no length, width, or height.
questions.explanation_correct: A point is a location in space with no length, width, or height. It is the most basic element in geometry, and is used to define other shapes and figures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'point'. A point is a location in space that has no size or dimensions - it is just a single spot. It is not a shape like a square or circle, which have length and width. So the missing word in the sentence should be 'point'.

questions.question_text: Railway tracks are an example of ___ lines because they never meet.
questions.explanation_correct: Railway tracks are an example of parallel lines because they never meet or intersect each other. Parallel lines are lines that stay the same distance apart and never cross or touch, no matter how far they go.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'parallel' lines. Parallel lines are lines that never meet or intersect, even if you extend them really far. Railway tracks are a good example of parallel lines because they stay the same distance apart and never cross each other. The tracks do not form 'perpendicular' or 'intersecting' lines.

questions.question_text: The distance from the centre of a circle to any point on the circle is called the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The distance from the center of a circle to any point on the circle is called the radius. This is because the radius is a straight line that connects the center of the circle to the edge or circumference of the circle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The distance from the center of a circle to any point on the circle is not called the diameter. The diameter is the distance across the circle, passing through the center. The radius is the correct answer, as it is the distance from the center to the edge of the circle.

questions.question_text: If the diameter of a circle is 12 cm, then its radius is ___ cm.
questions.explanation_correct: The radius of a circle is half the diameter. Since the diameter is 12 cm, the radius must be 6 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The diameter of a circle is the distance across the circle, passing through the center. To find the radius, you need to divide the diameter by 2. So if the diameter is 12 cm, the radius is 6 cm. The accepted answer format is a single number, so the correct answer is 6 cm.

questions.question_text: When you fold a shape along its line of symmetry, both halves match exactly. This property is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: When you fold a shape along its line of symmetry, both halves match exactly. This property is called symmetry, because the two sides are mirror images of each other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The property where both halves of a shape match exactly when you fold it along a line is called symmetry. The exact answer format is 'symmetry'. Some students may think that the property is called 'matching' or 'folding', but that is not correct. Symmetry is the right term for when the two sides of a shape are the same.

questions.question_text: A pattern made by repeating shapes without gaps or overlaps is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A pattern made by repeating shapes without gaps or overlaps is called a tessellation. This is because the shapes fit together perfectly, like a puzzle, to cover a surface completely.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'tessellation'. This is a pattern made by repeating the same shape over and over, with no gaps or overlaps between the shapes. The shapes fit together perfectly to cover a surface. The wrong answer would be something like 'collage' or 'mosaic', which are patterns made by putting different shapes together, not just repeating the same shape.

questions.question_text: An open curve has endpoints and does not enclose a region.
questions.explanation_correct: An open curve has endpoints and does not enclose a region. This means that the curve is not closed and can be extended on both sides without meeting at any point.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A closed curve encloses a region and has no endpoints. This means that the curve connects back to itself and forms a complete shape that surrounds an area. An open curve, on the other hand, has endpoints and does not enclose a region.

questions.question_text: All polygons are simple closed curves made only of straight line segments.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, that's correct! A polygon is a simple closed curve made up of only straight line segments. The key features are that it is closed (the starting and ending points meet) and the sides are all straight lines, not curved.
questions.explanation_incorrect: No, that is not correct. A polygon is a closed curve, but it can have curved sides, not just straight line segments. For example, a circle is a closed curve, but it has a curved side, so it is not a polygon. Polygons are specifically made up of only straight line segments that meet at corners or vertices.

questions.question_text: A rectangle and a square both have 4 right angles, but a square has all sides equal while a rectangle has only opposite sides equal.
questions.explanation_correct: The statement is true. Both a rectangle and a square have 4 right angles, which means all their angles are 90 degrees. However, a square has all 4 sides equal, while a rectangle has only the opposite sides equal in length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is not false. It is true that a rectangle and a square both have 4 right angles. The difference is that a square has all 4 sides equal in length, while a rectangle has only the opposite sides equal. So the statement correctly describes the properties of a rectangle and a square.

questions.question_text: Every square is a rectangle, but not every rectangle is a square.
questions.explanation_correct: Every square is a rectangle because a square has four equal sides and four right angles, which are the properties of a rectangle. However, not every rectangle is a square, because a rectangle can have different lengths for its sides, while a square must have all four sides equal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is not correct. It is true that every square is a rectangle, but it is also true that every rectangle is a square. This is because a square is a special type of rectangle, where all four sides are equal in length and all four angles are right angles. So, every square is a rectangle, and every rectangle is also a square.

questions.question_text: A line segment has two endpoints and a definite length.
questions.explanation_correct: A line segment has two endpoints, which means the line segment starts at one point and ends at another point. The line segment also has a definite length, meaning it can be measured from one endpoint to the other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A line, on the other hand, does not have a definite length. It continues on forever in both directions. A line segment is a part of a line that has a definite starting and ending point, and can be measured from one end to the other.

questions.question_text: Perpendicular lines always meet at a right angle, while parallel lines never meet at all.
questions.explanation_correct: Perpendicular lines always meet at a right angle (90 degrees). Parallel lines never meet because they are always the same distance apart and never intersect.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not true that parallel lines never meet at all. Parallel lines are lines that are the same distance apart and never cross each other. However, perpendicular lines, which meet at a right angle, are not the only way lines can intersect. Lines can also meet at other angles besides 90 degrees.

questions.question_text: The diameter of a circle passes through the centre and is the longest distance across the circle.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, the statement is true. The diameter of a circle is the longest distance across the circle, and it always passes through the centre of the circle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false because the radius of a circle is the distance from the centre to the edge, while the diameter is the longest distance across the circle and passes through the centre. The diameter is always twice the length of the radius.

questions.question_text: If the radius of a circle is 7 cm, then the diameter is 14 cm.
questions.explanation_correct: The radius of a circle is the distance from the centre to the edge. If the radius is 7 cm, then the diameter, which is the distance across the circle passing through the centre, must be 2 times the radius, which is 14 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be thinking that the diameter is not double the radius. But the diameter of a circle is always twice the radius. So if the radius is 7 cm, the diameter must be 14 cm.

questions.question_text: A line of symmetry divides a shape into two parts that are mirror images of each other.
questions.explanation_correct: A line of symmetry divides a shape into two parts that are mirror images of each other. This means the two parts are exactly the same on both sides of the line of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some people may think a line of symmetry does not divide a shape into two mirror image parts. But this is not correct. A line of symmetry always cuts the shape in half, so that the two halves are exactly the same and can be folded along the line to match up perfectly.

questions.question_text: Tangrams are made up of 7 flat geometric pieces that can be arranged to form various shapes.
questions.explanation_correct: Tangrams are made up of 7 flat geometric pieces, usually in the shape of triangles, squares, and parallelograms. These pieces can be arranged in different ways to create various shapes and patterns.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tangrams are not made up of circular or curved pieces. They are made of 7 flat geometric shapes, usually triangles, squares, and parallelograms. These pieces can be arranged in different ways to create many different shapes and designs.

questions.question_text: Arrange these curves from simplest to most complex in terms of their properties:
questions.explanation_correct: The order from simplest to most complex is: Open curve, Closed curve, Simple closed curve, Polygon. An open curve has no starting or ending point, while a closed curve does. A simple closed curve is a special type of closed curve that does not cross itself. A polygon is a closed shape with straight sides, which is more complex than a simple closed curve.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order from simplest to most complex is: Open curve, Closed curve, Simple closed curve, Polygon. An open curve is the simplest as it has no starting or ending point. A closed curve is more complex as it has a starting and ending point that meet. A simple closed curve is even more complex as it is a special type of closed curve that does not cross itself. Finally, a polygon is the most complex as it is a closed shape with straight sides.

questions.question_text: Arrange these steps to draw a square correctly:
ordering_items: Draw a line segment of chosen length
Turn right by a right angle and draw equal length
Repeat two more times to complete the square
correct_answer: Draw a line segment of chosen length
Turn right by a right angle and draw equal length
Repeat two more times to complete the square
questions.explanation_correct: This is the correct order because to draw a square, you first need to mark a starting point, then draw a line segment of a chosen length. Next, you turn right by a right angle (90 degrees) and draw another line segment of the same length. Repeating this two more times will complete the square.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to start by turning right and drawing a line, then repeating this step. This would not create a square, as you need to first mark a starting point, then draw a line segment, and only then turn right and draw another equal line segment. Repeating this process three times in total will complete the square.

questions.question_text: Arrange these geometric objects from smallest to most extended:
questions.explanation_correct: The order from smallest to most extended is correct because a point is the smallest geometric object, a line segment is longer than a point, a line is even longer than a line segment, and a plane is the most extended of all, covering a large flat surface area.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The order should be from smallest to most extended, which is: point, line segment, line, plane. A point is the smallest geometric object, then a line segment which has length but no width, then a line which has length and can extend infinitely, and finally a plane which has length and width and can cover a large flat surface area.

questions.question_text: Arrange these steps to draw a circle using a compass:
ordering_items: Mark the centre point on paper
Set the compass to the desired radius
Place the compass point on the centre
Rotate the compass to draw the circle
correct_answer: Mark the centre point on paper
Set the compass to the desired radius
Place the compass point on the centre
Rotate the compass to draw the circle
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is important because you need to set the center point first, then adjust the compass to the desired radius, place the compass point on the center, and finally rotate the compass to draw the circle. This ensures the circle is drawn accurately with the right size and position.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to first rotate the compass without setting the center point or radius. This would not draw a proper circle, as the compass needs to be set up correctly before rotating. You must first mark the center, set the radius, and then rotate the compass around that center point to draw the circle.

questions.question_text: Arrange these steps to check if a shape has a line of symmetry:
ordering_items: Draw a line through the shape
Fold the shape along the line
Check if both halves match exactly
If they match, the line is a line of symmetry
correct_answer: Draw a line through the shape
Fold the shape along the line
Check if both halves match exactly
If they match, the line is a line of symmetry
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order of steps is important to check if a shape has a line of symmetry. First, you draw a line through the middle of the shape. Then, you fold the shape along that line. If the two halves match exactly, the line is a line of symmetry for that shape.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to first check if the two halves match, then fold the shape, and finally draw the line. This is not the right way because you need to first draw the line through the shape, then fold it along that line, and only then can you check if the two halves match exactly. If they do, then that line is a line of symmetry for the shape.

questions.question_text: Arrange these steps to create a tessellation pattern:
ordering_items: Choose a shape that can fit together without gaps
Place the second shape next to it with no gaps
correct_answer: Choose a shape that can fit together without gaps
Place the second shape next to it with no gaps
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is to first choose a shape that can fit together without gaps, then draw the first shape, place the second shape next to it with no gaps, and continue repeating this pattern. This is the correct way to create a tessellation pattern, where the shapes fit together perfectly without any spaces in between.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to first draw the first shape, then place the second shape next to it with no gaps, and continue repeating the pattern. This is not correct because you need to first choose a shape that can fit together without gaps before you can start drawing and placing the shapes. The shapes need to be able to fit together seamlessly to create a tessellation pattern.

questions.question_text: Arrange these polygons in order of increasing number of sides:
questions.explanation_correct: The polygons are arranged in the correct order because the number of sides increases from 3 (triangle) to 4 (quadrilateral) to 5 (pentagon) to 6 (hexagon). This is the correct order from least to most number of sides.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is not the correct order. The polygons should be arranged from the one with the least number of sides to the one with the most number of sides. A triangle has 3 sides, a quadrilateral has 4 sides, a pentagon has 5 sides, and a hexagon has 6 sides. The correct order is: Triangle, Quadrilateral, Pentagon, Hexagon.

questions.question_text: Arrange these quadrilaterals from most specific to most general properties:
ordering_items: Square (all sides equal, all angles right)
Rectangle (opposite sides equal, all angles right)
correct_answer: Square (all sides equal, all angles right)
Rectangle (opposite sides equal, all angles right)
questions.explanation_correct: The quadrilaterals are arranged from most specific to most general properties. A square has the most specific properties with all sides equal and all angles right. A rectangle has slightly more general properties with opposite sides equal and all angles right. A parallelogram has even more general properties with opposite sides equal and parallel. Finally, a quadrilateral is the most general four-sided polygon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to arrange the quadrilaterals from most general to most specific properties. This would make the order: Quadrilateral (any four-sided polygon), Parallelogram (opposite sides equal and parallel), Rectangle (opposite sides equal, all angles right), Square (all sides equal, all angles right). This is wrong because we want to arrange the shapes from the most specific properties to the most general.

questions.question_text: Arrange these steps to identify perpendicular lines:
ordering_items: Check the angle where they meet
Verify if the angle is a right angle
If yes, the lines are perpendicular
correct_answer: Check the angle where they meet
Verify if the angle is a right angle
If yes, the lines are perpendicular
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is: Find two lines that meet, Check the angle where they meet, Verify if the angle is a right angle, If yes, the lines are perpendicular. This is because to identify if two lines are perpendicular, you first need to find the lines that meet, then check the angle between them, and if the angle is 90 degrees, then the lines are perpendicular.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: Verify if the angle is a right angle, Find two lines that meet, Check the angle where they meet, If yes, the lines are perpendicular. This is wrong because you need to first find the two lines that meet, then check the angle between them, and only if the angle is 90 degrees can you say the lines are perpendicular.

questions.question_text: Arrange these circle measurements from smallest to largest when radius is 4 cm:
questions.explanation_correct: The radius of a circle is the distance from the center to the edge, so it is the smallest measurement. The diameter is twice the radius, so it is the next largest. The half circumference is half the full circumference, which is calculated using the formula 2 x π x radius, so it is the third largest. The full circumference is the largest of the given measurements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If you think the full circumference is the smallest measurement, that's not correct. The full circumference is calculated using the formula 2 x π x radius, which is the largest of the given measurements. The radius is the smallest, then the diameter, then the half circumference, and finally the full circumference.

questions.question_text: What is the description: of Open curve?

options.text: Has endpoints and does not enclose a region
Simple closed curve with all points at equal distance from centre
Has no endpoints and encloses a region
Simple closed curve made of straight line segments

questions.explanation_correct: An open curve has endpoints and does not enclose a region. This means the curve starts at one point and ends at another point, without closing back on itself to form a shape.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An open curve is different from a closed curve. A closed curve has no endpoints and encloses a region, like a circle. But an open curve has endpoints, meaning it starts and ends at different points, and does not enclose any region. Options B, C, and D describe closed curves, not open curves.

questions.question_text: What is the description: of Closed curve?

options.text: Has no endpoints and encloses a region
Simple closed curve with all points at equal distance from centre
Simple closed curve made of straight line segments
Has endpoints and does not enclose a region

questions.explanation_correct: A closed curve has no endpoints and encloses a region. This means the curve loops back on itself to form a complete shape, without any open ends.
questions.explanation_incorrect: B and C are not correct because they describe other types of closed curves, like circles and polygons. D is not correct because a closed curve does not have endpoints and it does enclose a region. Only option A correctly describes a closed curve as having no endpoints and enclosing a region.

questions.question_text: What is the description: of Polygon?

options.text: Simple closed curve with all points at equal distance from centre
Simple closed curve made of straight line segments
Has no endpoints and encloses a region
Has endpoints and does not enclose a region

questions.explanation_correct: A polygon is a simple closed curve made of straight line segments. This means it is a shape with straight sides that forms a closed loop, with no gaps or overlaps.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A polygon is not a simple closed curve with all points at equal distance from the centre, which is the description of a circle. It also does not have no endpoints and enclose a region, which is the description of a closed curve. And it is not a shape with endpoints that does not enclose a region, which is the description of an open curve.

questions.question_text: What is the description: of Circle?

options.text: Has endpoints and does not enclose a region
Has no endpoints and encloses a region
Simple closed curve made of straight line segments
Simple closed curve with all points at equal distance from centre

questions.explanation_correct: A circle is a simple closed curve where all points on the curve are at an equal distance from the centre. This means the shape encloses a region and has no endpoints.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B describes an open curve that does not enclose a region, like a line or arc. Option C describes a polygon with straight line segments, which is different from a circle. Option A does not match the description of a circle, which is a closed curve that encloses a region.

questions.question_text: What shape is Rectangle?
questions.explanation_correct: The shape of a rectangle is 4 right angles, with opposite sides being equal. This means that a rectangle has 4 corners that form 90-degree angles, and the lengths of the opposite sides are the same.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is the correct answer. A rectangle has 4 right angles, which means all the angles are 90 degrees. The opposite sides of a rectangle are also equal in length. This is different from a shape with 3 sides and 3 corners (Option A), or a shape with 4 sides all equal (Option C), or a shape with 5 sides and 5 corners (Option D).

questions.question_text: What shape is Square?
questions.explanation_correct: A square has 4 right angles and all 4 sides are equal in length. This makes it a special type of rectangle, where all the sides have the same measurement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not correct because a square has 4 sides and 4 corners, not 3 (option A) or 5 (option B). Also, a square has 4 right angles, which means all the angles are 90 degrees (option C is not fully correct).

questions.question_text: What shape is Triangle?
questions.explanation_correct: A triangle is a shape with 3 sides and 3 corners, so option B is the correct answer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A describes a rectangle, which has 4 right angles and opposite sides that are equal. Option C describes a pentagon, which has 5 sides and 5 corners. Option D describes a square, which has 4 right angles and all 4 sides equal. None of these options match the definition of a triangle, which is the shape with 3 sides and 3 corners.

questions.question_text: What shape is Pentagon?
questions.explanation_correct: A pentagon has 5 sides and 5 corners, so the correct answer is D. A pentagon is a closed shape with 5 straight sides meeting at 5 corners or vertices.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not pentagons. A is a square, B is a triangle, and C is a rectangle. A pentagon has more than 3 sides and corners, so the correct answer is D with 5 sides and 5 corners.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of Point?

options.text: A location in space with no size
Lines that meet at right angles
Part of a line with two endpoints

questions.explanation_correct: A point is a location in space that has no size. It is just a specific place, like the tip of a pencil or the corner of a square. Points are the building blocks of all shapes and figures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is correct because a point has no length, width, or height. It is simply a location in space. Options B, C, and D describe different types of lines and shapes, not a point. A point is the most basic element in geometry, and it does not extend or have any size.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of Line?

options.text: Part of a line with two endpoints
A location in space with no size
Lines that meet at right angles

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) Extends infinitely in both directions. A line is a straight path that goes on forever, with no endpoints. It just keeps going in a single direction without stopping.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not the correct meaning of a line. Option A) describes a line segment, which has two endpoints. Option B) describes a point, which has no size. Option D) describes perpendicular lines, which meet at right angles, not the definition of a line itself. The key feature of a line is that it extends infinitely in both directions.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of Line segment?

options.text: A location in space with no size
Lines that meet at right angles
Part of a line with two endpoints

questions.explanation_correct: A line segment is a part of a line with two endpoints. It has a definite length and is not infinite like a full line.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option C is correct because a line segment is a part of a line that has two endpoints, meaning it has a definite starting and ending point. It is not a location with no size (option A), nor is it a line that extends infinitely in both directions (option D). Perpendicular lines (option B) are different from line segments.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of Perpendicular lines?

options.text: Lines that meet at right angles
Part of a line with two endpoints
A location in space with no size

questions.explanation_correct: Perpendicular lines are lines that meet at right angles, or 90 degrees. They form a perfect 'L' shape where the lines cross. This is the best answer because it describes the key property of perpendicular lines.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B, 'Lines that meet at right angles', is the correct answer. This means the lines cross each other at exactly 90 degrees, forming a perfect 'L' shape. Option A, 'Extends infinitely in both directions', is not correct because perpendicular lines don't necessarily extend forever. Option C, 'Part of a line with two endpoints', is not correct because perpendicular lines don't have to be just a segment of a line. Option D, 'A location in space with no size', is not correct because perpendicular lines are not just a point in space but actual lines that intersect at a right angle.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of Centre?

options.text: The boundary or perimeter of the circle
The middle point of the circle
Distance across the circle through the centre
Distance from centre to the circle

questions.explanation_correct: The centre of a circle is the middle point. It is the special point in the middle of the circle where all the lines from the edge to the centre are the same length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The centre of a circle is not the boundary or perimeter of the circle. The perimeter is the distance around the outside of the circle. The centre is also not the distance across the circle through the centre, which is called the diameter. The centre is also not the distance from the centre to the circle, which is called the radius. The correct answer is that the centre is the middle point of the circle.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of Radius?

options.text: The boundary or perimeter of the circle
Distance across the circle through the centre
Distance from centre to the circle
The middle point of the circle

questions.explanation_correct: The radius is the distance from the center of the circle to the circle's edge. This means option C, 'Distance from centre to the circle', is the correct meaning of radius.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The radius is not the boundary or perimeter of the circle (option A). The radius also does not mean the middle point of the circle (option D). The radius is the line that goes from the center of the circle to the edge, so the correct answer is option C, 'Distance from centre to the circle'.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of Diameter?

options.text: The middle point of the circle
Distance from centre to the circle
The boundary or perimeter of the circle
Distance across the circle through the centre

questions.explanation_correct: The diameter is the distance across the circle through the centre. It is the longest straight line that can be drawn inside the circle, passing through the middle point.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The diameter is not the middle point of the circle, nor the distance from the centre to the circle. It also does not mean the boundary or perimeter of the circle. The diameter is the longest straight line that can be drawn inside the circle, passing through the centre.

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of Circumference?

options.text: Distance from centre to the circle
The boundary or perimeter of the circle
Distance across the circle through the centre
The middle point of the circle

questions.explanation_correct: The circumference is the boundary or perimeter of the circle. It is the distance all the way around the outside of the circle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The circumference is not the distance from the centre to the circle (option A), nor is it the distance across the circle through the centre (option C). The circumference is the boundary or perimeter of the circle, which is the distance all the way around the outside. The middle point of the circle is called the centre (option D).

questions.question_text: What shape is Circle?
questions.explanation_correct: A circle has an infinite number of lines of symmetry because it is perfectly round and symmetrical in all directions. This means you can draw an infinite number of lines through the center of the circle, and the two halves on either side will be exactly the same.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not correct because they do not describe the properties of a circle. A circle is a closed curve with no straight sides, and it has an infinite number of lines of symmetry, meaning you can draw an infinite number of lines through the center and the two halves will be exactly the same. Options A, B, and D describe the number of lines of symmetry for other shapes, not a circle.

questions.question_text: What shape is Square?
questions.explanation_correct: A square has 4 lines of symmetry, which are the two diagonal lines and the two sides. This means you can fold the square in 4 different ways and the two halves will perfectly match up. This makes the square a very symmetrical and balanced shape.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not correct for a square. A square does not have 3 lines of symmetry, nor does it have infinite lines of symmetry. It also does not have only 2 lines of symmetry. The correct answer is that a square has 4 lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: What shape is Rectangle (not square)?
questions.explanation_correct: A rectangle (not a square) has 2 lines of symmetry. This means if you fold the rectangle in half along the vertical or horizontal axis, the two halves will match perfectly. This property makes a rectangle different from other shapes like a square, which has 4 lines of symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A rectangle does not have 3, 4, or infinite lines of symmetry. It has exactly 2 lines of symmetry - one vertical line and one horizontal line. This is because a rectangle has 4 sides of equal length, but the opposite sides are parallel, unlike a square which has 4 equal sides and 4 equal angles.

questions.question_text: What shape is Equilateral triangle?
questions.explanation_correct: An equilateral triangle has 3 lines of symmetry because it has 3 equal sides and 3 equal angles. This means you can draw 3 lines that divide the triangle into two identical halves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An equilateral triangle does not have infinite lines of symmetry. It has exactly 3 lines of symmetry because it has 3 equal sides and 3 equal angles. The other options are incorrect because a 4-sided shape has 4 lines of symmetry, and a circle has infinite lines of symmetry, but an equilateral triangle has 3 lines of symmetry.

questions.question_text: What is the what you see when looking at a cube: of Front view?

options.text: The face you see when looking from above
The face you see when looking straight ahead
The face you see from the left or right

questions.explanation_correct: The front view of a cube is the face you see when looking straight ahead. This is because a cube has 6 identical square faces, and the front face is the one facing you.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The front view of a cube is not identical squares, the top view, or the left/right view. It is the face you see when looking straight at the cube, which is one of the 6 square faces of the cube.

questions.question_text: What is the what you see when looking at a cube: of Side view?

options.text: The face you see when looking straight ahead
The face you see from the left or right
The face you see when looking from above

questions.explanation_correct: The side view of a cube is the face you see from the left or right, which is a square. This is because a cube has 6 square faces, and you will see one of those square faces when looking at the cube from the side.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The side view of a cube is not identical squares, as that would be the view from the top or bottom. The side view is also not the face you see when looking straight ahead, as that would be the front view. The side view is also not the face you see when looking from above, as that would be the top view. The correct answer is the face you see from the left or right, which is a square.

questions.question_text: What is the what you see when looking at a cube: of Top view?

options.text: The face you see from the left or right
The face you see when looking from above
The face you see when looking straight ahead

questions.explanation_correct: When you look at a cube from the top, you see a square. This is because the top face of a cube is a square shape.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The top view of a cube is not the side face or the front face. The top view shows the square shape of the top face of the cube. This is because a cube has six square faces, and when you look at it from the top, you see one of those square faces.

questions.question_text: What is the what you see when looking at a cube: of All three views of a cube?

options.text: The face you see when looking from above
The face you see from the left or right
The face you see when looking straight ahead

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) Identical squares. When you look at a cube, you see six identical square faces on all sides of the cube.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer is D) The face you see when looking straight ahead. A cube is a 3D shape, so no matter which direction you look at it from, you will always see identical square faces. It is not just the front face that you see, but all six square faces of the cube.

questions.question_text: What property is used to sort "All sides equal and all angles right"?
questions.explanation_correct: The property 'all sides equal and all angles right' is used to sort squares. Squares have all four sides equal and all four angles at 90 degrees, which makes them a special type of rectangle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The property 'all sides equal and all angles right' is used to sort squares, not rectangles, trapeziums, or rhombi. Rectangles have opposite sides equal and all angles right, but the sides don't have to be all equal. Trapeziums and rhombi have different properties that do not match this description.

questions.question_text: What property is used to sort "Opposite sides equal and all angles right"?
questions.explanation_correct: The property 'opposite sides equal and all angles right' is used to sort the shape 'Rectangle'. This is because a rectangle has four right angles (all 90 degrees) and its opposite sides are equal in length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The property 'opposite sides equal and all angles right' is not used to sort a Rhombus, Trapezium, or Square. A Rhombus has four equal sides but not all angles are right. A Trapezium has one pair of parallel sides, but not all angles are right. A Square has four right angles and all sides are equal, but it is a special type of Rectangle.

questions.question_text: What property is used to sort "All sides equal but no right angles"?
questions.explanation_correct: The shape described, 'all sides equal but no right angles', is a rhombus. This is because a rhombus has four equal sides, but the angles are not all right angles (90 degrees) like in a square.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The shape described is not a square, because a square has all sides equal and all angles are right angles. It is also not a trapezium, which has two parallel sides, or a rectangle, which has all angles as right angles. The correct shape is a rhombus, which has all sides equal but the angles are not right angles.

questions.question_text: What property is used to sort "Only one pair of parallel sides"?
questions.explanation_correct: The property of having 'only one pair of parallel sides' is used to sort a Trapezium, which is a four-sided shape with exactly one pair of parallel sides.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B, Trapezium, is the correct answer because a Trapezium is a four-sided shape with exactly one pair of parallel sides. Options A, Rectangle, and D, Square, both have two pairs of parallel sides, while Option C, Rhombus, has all four sides equal in length, but no parallel sides.

questions.question_text: What is the the line type it represents: of Railway tracks?
questions.explanation_correct: Railway tracks are parallel lines because they run side-by-side and never cross each other. Parallel lines are lines that stay the same distance apart from each other no matter how far they go.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Railway tracks are not perpendicular lines because perpendicular lines intersect and form a right angle (90 degrees) between them. Railway tracks run alongside each other and do not intersect, so the correct answer is that they represent parallel lines.

questions.question_text: What is the the line type it represents: of Corners of a book?
questions.explanation_correct: The corners of a book represent perpendicular lines because the sides of the book meet at right angles, forming a 90-degree angle. Perpendicular lines intersect at a 90-degree angle, which is exactly what we see at the corners of a book.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The corners of a book do not represent parallel lines because parallel lines never intersect and are always the same distance apart. The sides of the book meet at right angles, so the correct answer is perpendicular lines, not parallel lines.

questions.question_text: What is the the line type it represents: of Opposite edges of a ruler?
questions.explanation_correct: The opposite edges of a ruler represent parallel lines. Parallel lines are lines that run alongside each other and never intersect, like the edges of a ruler.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The opposite edges of a ruler do not represent perpendicular lines. Perpendicular lines intersect at right angles, forming a 90 degree angle. The edges of a ruler are parallel, meaning they are always the same distance apart and never meet.

questions.question_text: What is the the line type it represents: of The plus sign (+)?
questions.explanation_correct: The plus sign (+) represents perpendicular lines, which are lines that cross each other at right angles (90 degrees). This is because the arms of the plus sign are straight lines that meet at right angles, forming the shape of a cross.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The plus sign (+) does not represent parallel lines, which are lines that are always the same distance apart and never cross each other. Parallel lines are represented by two straight lines that run alongside each other, like the lines on a road. The plus sign has intersecting lines, which are perpendicular, not parallel.

questions.question_text: What is the the corresponding diameter: of Radius = 3 cm?
questions.explanation_correct: The diameter is twice the radius, so if the radius is 3 cm, the diameter is 6 cm. This is the correct answer (option C).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The diameter of a circle is not 20 cm or 16 cm, because it is always exactly twice the radius. Since the radius is 3 cm, the diameter must be 6 cm (option C).

questions.question_text: What is the the corresponding diameter: of Radius = 5 cm?
questions.explanation_correct: The diameter of a circle is twice the radius. So, if the radius is 5 cm, the diameter is 10 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The diameter of a circle is the distance across the circle, passing through the center. It is not 16 cm or 20 cm, as those are not double the given radius of 5 cm. The diameter is also not 6 cm, as that is not the correct relationship between the radius and the diameter of a circle.

questions.question_text: What is the the corresponding diameter: of Radius = 8 cm?
questions.explanation_correct: If the radius of a circle is 8 cm, then the diameter of the circle is twice the radius, which is 16 cm. The diameter is the distance across the circle, from one side to the other, and it is always twice the radius.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The diameter of a circle is always twice the radius. So, if the radius is 8 cm, the diameter must be 16 cm, not 6 cm, 20 cm, or 10 cm. The diameter is the longest distance across the circle, and it is directly related to the radius, which is the distance from the center to the edge of the circle.

questions.question_text: What is the the corresponding diameter: of Radius = 10 cm?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) Diameter = 20 cm. This is because the diameter of a circle is twice the length of the radius. If the radius is 10 cm, then the diameter must be 20 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are not correct because they do not match the relationship between the radius and diameter of a circle. The diameter is always exactly twice the length of the radius. So if the radius is 10 cm, the diameter must be 20 cm.

questions.question_text: What is the description: of Line of symmetry?

options.text: Divides shape into two identical halves
Has at least one line of symmetry

questions.explanation_correct: A line of symmetry divides a shape into two identical halves. This means that if you fold the shape along the line of symmetry, the two sides will match up exactly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A, 'Divides shape into two identical halves'. This is because a line of symmetry is a line that cuts a shape in half, creating two sides that are mirror images of each other. Option B, 'Has at least one line of symmetry', is not the correct description of a line of symmetry itself. Option C, 'Mirror image of a shape', is also not correct, as a line of symmetry is the line that creates the mirror image, not the mirror image itself. Option D, 'Has no lines of symmetry', is the opposite of a line of symmetry, so it is not the correct description.

questions.question_text: What is the description: of Reflection?

options.text: Divides shape into two identical halves
Has at least one line of symmetry

questions.explanation_correct: Reflection is the mirror image of a shape. When you have a shape and you put a mirror next to it, the image you see in the mirror is the reflection of the shape. This is the correct description of a reflection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The description 'divides shape into two identical halves' is not correct. That is the definition of symmetry, not reflection. Reflection is when you have a shape and its mirror image, which is the exact same shape but flipped or reversed. The correct answer is that reflection is the mirror image of a shape.

questions.question_text: What is the description: of Symmetric shape?

options.text: Divides shape into two identical halves
Has at least one line of symmetry

questions.explanation_correct: A symmetric shape has at least one line of symmetry. This means the shape can be divided into two identical halves that match perfectly when folded along that line.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A symmetric shape has at least one line of symmetry, which divides the shape into two identical halves. It is not just a mirror image of a shape, as option D suggests. Shapes with no lines of symmetry, like option A, are not considered symmetric. The key characteristic of a symmetric shape is that it can be divided into two matching halves.

questions.question_text: What is the description: of Asymmetric shape?

options.text: Has at least one line of symmetry
Divides shape into two identical halves

questions.explanation_correct: An asymmetric shape has no lines of symmetry. This means that if you draw a line through the shape, the two halves on either side will not be identical. The shape cannot be divided into two matching halves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An asymmetric shape does not have any lines of symmetry. This means that there is no way to draw a line through the shape such that the two halves on either side are exactly the same. Option A describes a shape with at least one line of symmetry, which is the opposite of an asymmetric shape. Option B describes a shape that can be divided into two identical halves, which is also the opposite of an asymmetric shape. Option D describes a shape that is a mirror image of another shape, but an asymmetric shape has no such mirror image.
